TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed BitmapScalingMode extends System.Enum

Docs.summary: Specifies which algorithm is used to scale bitmap images.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When animating the scale of any bitmap, the default high-quality image re-sampling algorithm can sometimes consume sufficient system resources to cause frame rate degradation. This frame rate degradation can cause animations to skip frames or stutter. By setting the <xref:System.Windows.Media.RenderOptions.BitmapScalingMode%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.RenderOptions> object to F:System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.LowQuality?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True you can create a smoother animation when scaling a bitmap.
## Examples The following example shows how to set the BitmapScalingMode for an image object.
[!code-cs[RenderOptions#RenderOptionsSnippet2](../../add/codesnippet/CSharp/RenderOptionsSnippets/Window1.xaml.cs#renderoptionssnippet2)] [!code-vb[RenderOptions#RenderOptionsSnippet2](../../add/codesnippet/VisualBasic/renderoptionssnippets/window1.xaml.vb#renderoptionssnippet2)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode Fant = int32(2)

Docs.summary: Use very high quality Fant bitmap scaling, which is slower than all other bitmap scaling modes, but produces higher quality output.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode HighQuality = int32(2)

Docs.summary: Use high quality bitmap scaling, which is slower than F:System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.LowQuality?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True mode, but produces higher quality output. The F:System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.HighQuality?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True mode is the same as the F:System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.Fant?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True mode.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode Linear = int32(1)

Docs.summary: Use linear bitmap scaling, which is faster than F:System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.HighQuality?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True mode, but produces lower quality output.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode LowQuality = int32(1)

Docs.summary: Use bilinear bitmap scaling, which is faster than F:System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.HighQuality?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True mode, but produces lower quality output. The F:System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.LowQuality?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True mode is the same as the F:System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.Linear?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True mode.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode NearestNeighbor = int32(3)

Docs.summary: Use nearest-neighbor bitmap scaling, which provides performance benefits over F:System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.LowQuality?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True mode when the software rasterizer is used. This mode is often used to magnify a bitmap.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode Unspecified = int32(0)

Docs.summary: Use the default bitmap scaling mode, which is F:System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.Linear?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True.
